SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name LEWIS FLETCHER
Present Address MAJOR SASK
Pioneer Address DERRICK SASK
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1905
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 8

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 4

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once in 2 weeks in summer, once a week in winter.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Mostly on other days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly without an invitation.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Mostly at night.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Not usually except with bachelors.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) You better stay & have a bite to eat.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? None in early days.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? I was a bachelor, so some stayed home.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? There were quilting bees after the bachelors got married and just quilting bees.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. None. Dances came later when the women came in. The people in this community in the early days leaned to the Methodist religion and did not believe in dancing.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes, from 1913 on.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Usually on other days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

5. What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually in the morning.

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Not usually except with the host family.

7. Did you ever have "tea" then groups of neighbors came together to put up a knitting, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, we used to gather after the wedding and make quilts.

8. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the reasons were for, and how often they occurred.

9. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

10. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by car from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? No.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

School was built in 1913. All dances, box socials & picnics were held in the school after it was built, none in private houses. Christmas concert was held at school too.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Practically all except social calls. Before the school was built some dances were held in private houses but not many.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1921

What material was it made of? Lumber How large was it? 26 x 60

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) We continued to use the school house for dances and some other functions especially Christmas concerts and practicing softball on the grounds. Used the hall for

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? Babies covered up in corner.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? In school barn

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Encore! Whist Pedro

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular? Both round & square dances

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. I do not think so

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. A few frowned, some did not dance.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, Christmas parties, etc.)

If you have not described these on the school questionnaire, give dates.

School was built in 1913. First dance was held there in 1921.

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district?

Describe.

Basically all except social calls were held in private homes.

After the school was built, some dances were held in private homes.

What material was it made of? Lumber

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In village.

How large was it? 26 x 60

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

We continued to use the school house for dances and various other functions especially Christmas parties and for practicing basketball on the grounds, until the hall for an old barn.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9), did the entire family attend?

How were tables and chairs provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Euchre, Whist

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? Round and square dances

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. A few frowned, some did not dance.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Chivarees were not common. This is a dry thinly settled county with very few weddings in the early days. Most weddings were in winter with a social evening afterward. Most chivarees like in Ontario, too cold to stay outside.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Sask Grain Growers Association

Give the date and reason for it being organized. 1913. At first just for a social time, then to get fruit and vegetables cheaper. 1914 was a very dry year.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. 1913 sociality + education at first - not many members. 1914, dry year, shipped in fruit vegetables - most & settlers going. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? practically all

How many women belonged? none How often did it meet? monthly at first

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization? discussions on economic questions, debates, dances, picnics.

Now this did not take place in our own school but a neighboring school.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? yes

When was it organized? 1915

Approximately how many women belonged to it? about 12 at first

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

This other school - Derrick was built earlier than Summit Park and was used as a centre for the Grain Growers' Organization to meet. All Summit Park people went there in the early days.
12. What attempts at formalized or "social" do you remember in small towns such as Glovers and Harts when calling cards, visiting cards, etc.,?

13. Was the obituary known in your community? Describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were, any influences connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any plans or arrangements not already mentioned that were popular in visiting or social life.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Association in your community? If so, when did it begin? How many members were there?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

This other school—Dawson's—was built earlier than Summit Park and was used as a centre for the Grain Growers' Organization to meet. The Summit Park people went there in the early days.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1924, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

None

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? Box socials

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In the school, either Summit Park or Derrick. The Homemakers held their meetings in the homes at first. Later in the town hall.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Yes

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Sometimes in October year. Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? James Mowry, a farmer owned a moving picture machine. He used sunlight & mirror in the daytime, and gas light at night.

What were the slides about? I forget, a mixture of pictures - these were moving pictures.

The slides were provided by the church & were missionary pictures.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Basketball & softball

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Girls very often played with the boys. They also skipped rope and played in a playhouse.

Mention the name of each, date when it was first organized, its purpose, its size (large or small), who belonged (men, women, young people, etc.), within a school district only or not, connected in any way with the church, and included the surrounding community. 22. What games did boys play in summer? (列举夏季男孩常玩的游戏)

23. What games did girls play in summer? (列举夏季女孩常玩的游戏)

Girls very often played with the boys. They also skated.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Fox and hounds, some skating.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   Crokinole, checkers, Authors & other card

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   All the family

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   Lots of time

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   No

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
   Give year and month if possible. 1913 July

26. Who organized it? Sask Grain Growers Associa

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? Entire community

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Ball games, different races, horse races, etc.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Formed family groups at first

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Practically everything to eat, ice cream, lemonade etc.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   Started 2 P.M., ended 5 O'Clock A.M. danced all night.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with animals, things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Families formed groups

at bird

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

Started 2 P.M., ended 5 O'Clock A.M. lasted all night.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

There was a band at the fire pie, and the moving pictures in the daytime by sunlight through the use of mirror. This fire pie was held at Derrick school.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

In the early days there were a lot more people than later on. There was no railroad or town within 20 miles. Sunday School picnics came later, put only United Church fewer people. They sat off shelter something placed on the ground and all the people got around this. This was never done at a large community fire pie.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Changes in manner of making arrangements to eat 1915.

Other activities were introduced such as merry-go-round (the merry-go-round was introduced by Macleod brothers and was free bronco-busting, Rodeo).

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Baseball, horse races & different kinds of foot racing by men, women, children. All took part, even old men.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Baseball

What year? 1915

How long did it continue? For about 15 years

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

None

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

1914 Hockey

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? 1949 Curling
33. Describe any features or this place which you remember as outstanding.

There was a band at the fair nice and the morning.

34. Describe any different kinds of plants which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community plant, school, church, Sunday School, local family, food and drink, when held, etc.

In the early days there were a lot more people than today.

35. What changes have you noticed in plants since then? Give data when changes become noticeable.

Other activities were introduced such as mostly around town.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, young people).

Basketball became a different kind of foot racing by men, women, children.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1915 - baseball

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1912, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). 1914 - hockey

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? 1946 - curling
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1915
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Yes
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Sask. Grain Growers' Assoc.
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). July or later, no special day

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates. No

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (use extra sheets if necessary)
I went west to Montana in 1897 and from there drifted up to Sedute county in 1902. From there to my present home site. The only books I held on to in my wanderings was the Bible, a dictionary (The Concise Imperial) & Shakespeare's plays. All the other books were dropped one place or another.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Some did
What kind of books and how many? As far as I remember the books brought in were novels

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Not many
I got books from Wheat Pool Library

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? None

Yes! Summit Park School had one 1941
Major Homemakers had one in Major & community 1936-48

48. Was there a school library? Yes
When was it begun? 1913
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Very little

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Not very much

I went out to Montana in 1897 and often there drifted off to Butte county in 1902 from there to my friend's home. The only book I liked on to me was my wanderings with the Bible, a dictionary (The Concise Imperial) of Shakespeare's plays.

All the other books were shipped over place or another.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

No. In summer I worked till I was tired, cooked my meals to eat, then slept. Winter - I went out to work first 2 winters. Later I always had reading enough out of papers and magazines & odd books.
